abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Sagond Vineyards' Wolffer Estate 1999 dessert chardonnay; photo (Long Island Vines column) (M)

Labor Day, and the thoughts of laborers and the fruits of their labors, is tailor-made for the grape, and for wine producers. Once a year, a swig of enlightened chauvinism (emphasisis on ''vin'') is in order. This brings us to the Wolffer Estate '99 dessert chardonnay.
What, you may ask, is a dessert chardonnay?

At Sagpond Vineyards in Sagaponack, where the owner, Christian Wolffer, and the winemaker and general manager, Roman Roth, are German-born, a dessert chardonnay amounts to a riesling trockenbeerenauslese in drag.
Essentially this white is made like a riesling and displays its attributes, including, on a reduced scale, the price: $32.50 for a labor-intensive half-bottle.
Though not unknown, luscious dessert chardonnay is rare in New York State. (Fans of dessert wines from the Finger Lakes find its counterpart in late-harvest Vidal blanc and late-harvest vignoles.)
What dessert chardonnay, trockenbeerenauslese and Sauternes have in common is a fungus called Botrytis cinerea. (In German it's edelfaule, in French pourriture noble, in English noble rot.

In warm, humid weather, this mold pierces the skins of grapes left hanging for over-the-top ripening, dehydrating and transforming them. It increases the sugar content and imparts its own distinct flavors.
The result, after a slow fermentation, is a tiny yield (Mr. Roth made only 792 bottles) and a wine that is syrupy, ambrosial. Sip the velvety Wolffer dessert chardonnay is like sipping honey.
As usual, Mr. Roth's restrained style shows through. Though sweet, the wine is not cloying; its finish is near-dry, thanks to lively acidity.

Mr. Roth finds in the wine ''aromas of peach and apricots,'' a common feature of sweet riesling. Serve it slightly chilled, he recommends. It goes best, he finds, with ''fresh fruits or fruit sorbets or on its own.''
Since it isn't good for business, Mr. Roth can't tell you that if you drink it on Labor Day, you should go on a diet until Columbus Day.
